metadata.titleEn: Qilian Mountains integrated observatory network: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network (eddy covariance system of Yakou station, 2020)
metadata.description:
This dataset contains the flux measurements from the Yakou station eddy covariance system (EC) in the upper reaches of the Heihe integrated observatory network from January 1 to December 31 in 2020. The site (100.2421° E, 38.0142° N) was located in the Qilian County in Qinghai Province. The elevation is 4148 m. The EC was installed at a height of 3.2 m, and the sampling rate was 10 Hz. The sonic anemometer faced north, and the separation distance between the sonic anemometer and the CO2/H2O gas analyzer (CSAT3&Li7500A) was 0.15 m.
The raw data acquired at 10 Hz were processed using the Eddypro post-processing software, including the spike detection, lag correction of H2O/CO2 relative to the vertical wind component, sonic virtual temperature correction, coordinate rotation (2-D rotation), corrections for density fluctuation (Webb-Pearman-Leuning correction), and frequency response correction. The EC data were subsequently averaged over 30 min periods. The observation data quality was divided into three classes according to the quality assessment method of stationarity (Δst) and the integral turbulent characteristics test (ITC): class 1-3 (high quality), class 4-6 (good), class 7-8 (poor, better than gap filling data), class9 (rejected). In addition to the above processing steps, the half-hourly flux data were screened in a four-step procedure: (1) data from periods of sensor malfunction were rejected; (2) data collected before or after 1 h of precipitation were rejected; (3) incomplete 30 min data were rejected when the missing data constituted more than 3% of the 30 min raw record. There were 48 records per day, and the missing data were replaced with -6999. Suspicious data were marked in red. The power loss occurs occasionally at this site. 
The released data contained the following variables: data/time, wind direction (Wdir, °), wind speed (Wnd, m/s), the standard deviation of the lateral wind (Std_Uy, m/s), virtual temperature (Tv, ℃), H2O mass density (H2O, g/m3), CO2 mass density (CO2, mg/m3), friction velocity (ustar, m/s), stability (z/L), sensible heat flux (Hs, W/m2), latent heat flux (LE, W/m2), carbon dioxide flux (Fc, mg/ (m2s)), quality assessment of the sensible heat flux (QA_Hs), quality assessment of the latent heat flux (QA_LE), and quality assessment of the carbon flux (QA_Fc). In this dataset, the time of 0:30 corresponds to the average data for the period between 0:00 and 0:30; the data were stored in *.xls format. Detailed information can be found in the suggested references.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) and Che et al. (2019) (for sites information), Liu et al. (2011) for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: The alpine region is important in riverine and watershed ecosystems as a contributor of freshwater, providing and stimulating specific habitats for biodiversity. In parallel, recent climate change, human activities, and other perturbations may disturb hydrological processes and eco-functions, creating the need for next-generation observational and modeling approaches to advance a predictive understanding of such processes in the alpine region. Water resources in the alpine region are headwaters that need to be regulated to sustain downstream ecosystems. However, perturbations induced by nature/climate change and human activities in recent years have significantly reformed hydrological processes and eco-functions. Accurate estimation and prediction of hydrological processes and their key impact factors has since become crucial.

Unfortunately, the scarcity of observation data in the alpine region, due to the difficulties of access and technological barriers, has hindered alpine hydrological modeling and associated research yet motivated the development of next-generation ecosystem observation networks and experiments. In comparison with the observations, using remote sensing data combined with data assimilation could improve the prediction of hydrological processes. However, due to the complexities of the earth system, there exist various sources of uncertainties in remote sensing data (especially in the alpine region), which have to be validated and calibrated. In summary, to fill the knowledge gap and promote alpine region hydrology research, an integrated, distributed and multiscale observation dataset is essential and expected to provide accurate forcing data for hydrological modeling, validate remote sensing data, allow the evaluation of distributed models and ultimately improve a predictive understanding of alpine hydrological processes and ecosystem functions. In alpine hydrology, in addition to consistent hydrometeorological data obtained from distributed meteorological stations, snow cover and frozen ground are two important indexes and driving forces that manipulate hydrological processes. The maximum snow water equivalent (SWE) before ablation determines the storage of snowmelt – a major source of freshwater in the alpine region, while freeze-thaw cycles (FTCs) and soil moisture within the active layer alter water infiltration and, consequently, surface runoff and groundwater. To promote alpine hydrology research, the International Network for Alpine Research Catchment Hydrology (INARCH) was launched in 2015 by the Global Energy and Water Exchanges (GEWEX) project of the World Climate Research Programme (WCRP), involving 18 catchments around the world. The INARCH has since connected individual observatories into an international network and data-share platform to lead frontier research on alpine region hydrometeorology and snow observation. Another community-based observation network, the Circumpolar Active Layer Monitoring (CALM) network, was initiated in the early 1990s to observe the response of the active layer and near-surface permafrost to climate change. The Heihe River Basin (HRB) is the second largest inland river basin in China and is known for its heterogeneous landscapes, diverse ecosystems, unique geographical characteristics and climate change over recent decades. As a major component of the ecohydrological processes in the arid/semi-arid HRB, the alpine hydrological processes, especially those related to snow cover and frozen ground in the upper reaches, have great impacts on runoff in the mountainous region, which then regulate agricultural development in the middle reaches and the ecosystems of the lower reaches.

In recent years, with climate warming, permafrost degradation has significantly affected runoff and the carbon cycle (Peng et al., 2016; Gao et al., 2018). Snow cover is widely distributed with unique characteristics in the study area. In the high-altitude mountainous region (elevation > 3800 m), influenced by the local microclimate and low temperature, snowfall could occur in any season. Temporary snow is the major snow cover type in the region at middle and low elevations because strong solar radiation and high air temperature lead to fast melting and sublimation of the snow. Drifting snow is also commonly observed in the region, which may lead to the redistribution of snowpack in high elevation regions (Essery et al., 1999; Li et al., 2014).

Blowing (drifting) snow is commonly observed in the Qilian mountain due to its high altitude and complex terrain. It is important to estimate the occurrence of blowing snow because it may cause redistributions of the snow cover and influence the sublimation of snow.

Soil heat conductivity is difficult to analyze because it is a function of soil density, soil moisture content (ice content in frozen ground), and soil temperature, which cannot be easily calculated using a simple formula. Therefore, site observations can be utilized to evaluate the parameterization of alpine hydrologic models.
research objective: The current study presents a suite of datasets consisting of long-term hydrometeorological, snow cover, and frozen ground data for investigating watershed science and functions from an integrated, distributed, and multiscale observation network in the upper reaches of the Heihe River Basin (HRB) in China.
This paper introduces the infrastructure of the integrated alpine hydrology observation network in the HRB and the complete datasets collected in recent years.

The associated open-access datasets include high-quality hydrometeorological data with specific respect to snow and frozen ground observations at the sub-basin and basin scales, which aims to address a variety of scientific questions including but not limited to: (1) how to provide accurate and effective forcing data for alpine hydrological models, (2) how to integrate observation, simulation and the acquired datasets for informative understanding, and (3) how perturbations (climate change and human activities) alter fundamental processes.

methods: Gap-free meteorological and hydrological data were monitored from an observation network connecting a group of automatic meteorological stations (AMSs). In addition, to capture snow accumulation and ablation processes, snow cover properties were collected from a snow observation superstation using state-of-the-art techniques and instruments. High-resolution soil physics datasets were also obtained to capture the freeze-thaw processes from a frozen ground observation superstation.

Considering the characteristics of the study site, an integrated, distributed and multiscale hydrometeorological – snow – frozen ground observation network has been established with seven automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) and two superstations. At the basin scale, the observation aims to collect data for investigating the meteorological driving forces and for validation of the alpine hydrological models. At the sub-basin scale, small-scale observations and measurements focus on data such as precipitation, soil temperature and moisture, which are used to develop and improve hydrologic models, as well as to validate remote sensing products at medium to coarse resolutions (Jin et al., 2014). At the two superstations for snow cover and frozen ground observations, remote sensing products can be further validated using fine-resolution data. In total, seven AMSs, as well as the frozen ground and snow superstations (also incorporating meteorological observations), were established in the study area during the intensive observation period (IOP: 2013 -2014) to obtain the spatially distributed meteorological variables. After the IOP, four typical AMSs were selected and retained for continuous observation, which is expected to provide long-term datasets. The observed meteorological variables include wind (speed and direction), air temperature, humidity, infrared temperature, air pressure, four-component radiation, and precipitation. Accumulation and depletion processes were measured automatically at the Yakou snow superstation. The observed components included snow depth, snow water equivalent (SWE, measured by GammaMONitor, GMON), albedo of the snow surface and blowing (drifting) snow flux (measured by FlowCapt). Soil temperature and moisture were measured within six layers at each AMS, while evapotranspiration (ET) was observed by eddy covariance (EC) at three AMSs located in permafrost, seasonally frozen ground and a transient zone to observe freeze-thaw (FT) processes. At the sub-basin scale, a wireless sensor network (WSN) with 40 nodes was established to capture seasonal changes in soil temperature and moisture. At the A’rou frozen ground superstation, soil temperature and moisture profiles were intensively measured in eighteen layers to a depth of 3.2 m (in a nested pattern with more layers in the topsoil) to obtain the soil hydrothermal features under freeze-thaw cycles (FTCs). In addition, thermal conductivity and hydraulic conductivity in the topsoil were also measured to observe the dynamic hydrothermal processes within.

Snow depth was measured by SR50A (Campbell, USA), which determines the distance between the sensor and the target by sending out ultrasonic pulses and listening for the returning echoes reflected from the target. Snow water equivalent (SWE) was measured by GMON (CS725 GammaMONitor, Campbell, USA) from 2014/1/1 to 2017/12/31 at a temporal resolution of 6 hr. FlowCapt (IAV, Switzerland) was used to measure the number of blowing snow grains at 3 heights (0-1 m, 1-2 m, and 2-3 m) every 10 mins.
dataset: The current study presents a suite of datasets consisting of long-term hydrometeorological, snow cover, and frozen ground data for investigating watershed science and functions from an integrated, distributed, and multiscale observation network in the upper reaches of the Heihe River Basin (HRB) in China. Gap-free meteorological and hydrological data were monitored from an observation network connecting a group of automatic meteorological stations (AMSs). In addition, to capture snow accumulation and ablation processes, snow cover properties were collected from a snow observation superstation using state-of-the-art techniques and instruments. High-resolution soil physics datasets were also obtained to capture the freeze-thaw processes from a frozen ground observation superstation. The updated datasets were released to scientists with multidisciplinary backgrounds (i.e., cryosphere science, hydrology, and meteorology), and they are expected to serve as a testing platform to provide accurate forcing data and validate and evaluate remote sensing products and hydrological models for a broader community.

This paper introduces the infrastructure of the integrated alpine hydrology observation network in the HRB and the complete datasets collected in recent years. Composed of seven standard hydrometeorological stations, one snow superstation and one frozen ground superstation, the observation network serves as an integrated research platform aiming to provide prominent datasets (e.g., hydrometeorology, snow, and frozen ground) of the hydrometeorological processes in the upper reaches of the HRB, which is expected to support alpine region hydrological model development and simulations along with remote sensing observation.

A comprehensive snow dataset from the Yakou snow superstation has been updated since the summer of 2013. The observed snow variables included snow depth, snow water equivalent (SWE) and blowing (drifting) snow. Data obtained from 2014/1/1 to 2017/12/31 are summarized in Figure 4, with additional plots for precipitation, ET, soil temperature and moisture. The datasets are available from 2012/12/05 to 2017/12/31, with intermittent loss mostly due to power loss and sensor malfunctions at high altitudes.

In this paper, a suite of alpine hydrology datasets observed from an integrated, distributed and multiscale hydrometeorological – snow – frozen ground observation network in the upper reaches of the Heihe River Basin (HRB) is presented.

This dataset helps investigate watershed science and functions, providing accurate forcing data for hydrological models and validating remote sensing products.

Definition.Question: What does 'eddy covariance' mean in the context of data collection methods for alpine hydrology?
Definition.Answer: Eddy covariance is a data collection method used to measure and calculate vertical turbulent fluxes within the atmosphere. In the context of alpine hydrology, it involves the use of instruments like ultrasonic anemometers and CO2/H2O analyzers to gather data on various fluxes, such as heat, moisture, and carbon dioxide, over a specific surface, with the goal of understanding surface-atmosphere exchanges.

Interpretation.Question: How might the technological barriers in alpine regions affect the accuracy and consistency of hydrometeorological data collection methods?
Interpretation.Answer: The scarcity of observation data in alpine regions, due to difficulties of access and technological barriers, can hinder the accuracy and consistency of data collection. These challenges can affect the development of remote sensing technologies and alpine hydrological models, as well as the availability of high-quality data for parameterization.

Interpretation.Question: What implications do the unique characteristics of snow cover in high-altitude regions have on the methods used for data collection and analysis?
Interpretation.Answer: The unique characteristics of snow cover in high-altitude regions, such as temporary snow and drifting snow, influence data collection methods by requiring specific instruments to measure snow depth, snow water equivalent, and blowing snow. These factors necessitate site observations to validate and calibrate remote sensing data and model parameterization.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes challenges in collecting complete and consistent data in alpine regions, particularly in the context of hydrological modeling and ecosystem observation networks?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Several formidable challenges, including the cold and harsh climate, high altitude, and complex topography, inhibit complete and consistent data collection where/when needed, hindering the development of remote sensing technologies and alpine hydrological models. The scarcity of observation data due to access difficulties and technological barriers has also been a significant issue.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors have led to the development of international networks like INARCH for alpine hydrology research?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The need to promote alpine hydrology research due to climate change, human activities, and other perturbations affecting hydrological processes has led to the development of international networks like INARCH. These networks aim to connect individual observatories into an international network and data-share platform to lead frontier research on alpine region hydrometeorology and snow observation.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes of integrating remote sensing data with ground-based observations in alpine hydrological modeling?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating remote sensing data with ground-based observations could improve the prediction of hydrological processes by providing more comprehensive and accurate data. This integration helps validate and calibrate the remote sensing data, reducing uncertainties inherent in such data, especially in complex alpine environments. Consequently, this approach could enhance the accuracy of hydrological models and contribute to a better understanding of alpine hydrological processes and ecosystem functions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective behind developing an integrated, distributed, and multiscale observation network in alpine hydrology research?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective is to fill the knowledge gap and promote alpine region hydrology research by providing an integrated, distributed, and multiscale observation dataset. This dataset is essential to provide accurate forcing data for hydrological modeling, validate remote sensing data, allow the evaluation of distributed models, and ultimately improve a predictive understanding of alpine hydrological processes and ecosystem functions.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to incorporate snow cover and frozen ground observations in hydrometeorological datasets for alpine regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Incorporating snow cover and frozen ground observations is important because they are key indexes and driving forces that manipulate hydrological processes in alpine regions. The maximum snow water equivalent (SWE) before ablation determines the snowmelt storage, a major source of freshwater. Freeze-thaw cycles (FTCs) and soil moisture within the active layer alter water infiltration, surface runoff, and groundwater, thus having significant impacts on alpine hydrology.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the intentions behind using automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) and superstations in the observation network for data collection in alpine regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The intention behind using AMSs and superstations is to establish a robust observation network that can capture the detailed and dynamic processes of alpine hydrology. AMSs help monitor distributed meteorological variables for validation of alpine hydrological models, while superstations for snow cover and frozen ground observations provide fine-resolution data necessary for validating remote sensing products and understanding the freeze-thaw processes.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are involved in preparing and processing data from eddy covariance instruments to ensure quality and usability in alpine hydrological research?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The data from eddy covariance instruments are initially collected at 10Hz and then processed to 30-minute intervals using Eddypro software. The main processing steps include despiking, time delay correction, coordinate rotation (double rotation), frequency response correction, sonic temperature correction, and density (WPL) correction. Additionally, quality assessment is performed, focusing on atmospheric stationarity and turbulent similarity tests. Data screening involves removing erroneous data, excluding data around precipitation events, and discarding data with more than 10% missing in the 10Hz raw data for each 30-minute interval. Missing data are marked as -6999.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are snow cover and frozen ground data collected and utilized to support alpine hydrological modeling in the upper reaches of river basins?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Snow cover and frozen ground data are collected using an integrated observation network that includes automatic meteorological stations and superstations for snow and frozen ground. Snow depth is measured using ultrasonic sensors, and snow water equivalent is determined by gamma radiation sensors. Blowing snow flux is measured using specialized instruments. Soil temperature and moisture are monitored across multiple layers. These data are used to validate remote sensing products, provide accurate forcing data for hydrological models, and improve understanding of snow accumulation, ablation, and freeze-thaw processes.

Enablement.Question: What techniques and instruments enable the collection of detailed snow cover properties in alpine regions?
Enablement.Answer: Snow cover properties are collected from a snow observation superstation using state-of-the-art techniques and instruments, including measurements of snow depth, snow water equivalent (SWE), and blowing snow flux. Instruments like SR50A for snow depth, GammaMONitor (GMON) for SWE, and FlowCapt for blowing snow flux are utilized to capture accumulation and ablation processes.

Enablement.Question: What are the challenges and conditions that enable the continuous collection of high-quality data in alpine regions?
Enablement.Answer: Challenges in alpine regions include the harsh climate, high altitude, and complex topography, which inhibit complete and consistent data collection. However, advancements in automatic meteorological stations and observation superstations enable the continuous collection of high-quality data, despite issues like power loss and sensor malfunctions at high altitudes.

The scarcity of observation data in the alpine region, due to the difficulties of access and technological barriers, has hindered alpine hydrological modeling and associated research.

Expectation.Question: What are the expected benefits of integrating remote sensing data with ground observations in alpine hydrological research?
Expectation.Answer: Using remote sensing data combined with data assimilation could improve the prediction of hydrological processes. However, due to the complexities of the earth system, various sources of uncertainties in remote sensing data, especially in the alpine region, exist and have to be validated and calibrated. Integrating remote sensing with ground observations is expected to provide accurate forcing data for hydrological modeling, validate remote sensing data, and ultimately improve a predictive understanding of alpine hydrological processes and ecosystem functions.

Judgmental.Question: How do you evaluate the effectiveness of integrating remote sensing data with ground-based observations for improving alpine hydrological models?
Judgmental.Answer: The integration of remote sensing data with ground-based observations is crucial for improving alpine hydrological models due to the scarcity of direct observation data in alpine regions caused by difficult access and technological barriers. Remote sensing data, combined with data assimilation, can enhance the prediction of hydrological processes, although it introduces uncertainties that need validation and calibration. An integrated observation dataset is essential for providing accurate forcing data, validating remote sensing data, and improving predictive understanding of hydrological processes.

Judgmental.Question: What are the main challenges faced in maintaining continuous and consistent data collection in alpine regions, and how can they be addressed?
Judgmental.Answer: The main challenges in alpine regions include cold and harsh climates, high altitudes, and complex topography that inhibit complete and consistent data collection. These factors hinder the development of remote sensing technologies and alpine hydrological models. Addressing these challenges requires the establishment of integrated, distributed, and multiscale observation networks, utilizing advanced techniques and instruments to ensure gap-free data collection, even in difficult conditions.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, how can the development of next-generation ecosystem observation networks enhance the understanding of ecosystem functions in alpine regions?
Judgmental.Answer: Next-generation ecosystem observation networks can significantly enhance understanding by providing a comprehensive and multiscale dataset covering hydrometeorological, snow cover, and frozen ground data. These networks facilitate the integration of observations, simulations, and datasets, allowing for a deeper understanding of how perturbations such as climate change and human activities alter fundamental processes. They also enable the validation of remote sensing products and the development of improved hydrological models, which are critical for accurately predicting ecosystem functions in alpine regions.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how data collection methods can effectively deal with the challenges posed by harsh climate and complex topography in alpine regions.
Assertion.Answer: To address the harsh climate and complex topography challenges in alpine regions, an integrated, distributed, and multiscale hydrometeorological observation network has been established, incorporating automatic meteorological stations and superstations for snow and frozen ground observations. This setup allows for the collection of high-quality, gap-free data on various variables such as wind, temperature, humidity, snow depth, and soil moisture, using advanced instruments like ultrasonic sensors and gamma monitors.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges associated with collecting high-quality snow and frozen ground data in alpine regions and propose potential solutions or technological advancements that could address these challenges.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges in collecting high-quality snow and frozen ground data in alpine regions include the cold and harsh climate, high altitude, and complex topography, which hinder data collection and the development of remote sensing technologies and hydrological models. Technological advancements such as improved sensor durability, enhanced data collection networks like the use of automatic meteorological stations (AMSs), and the integration of observation networks with remote sensing data could potentially address these challenges.

Request/Directive.Question: Please propose a comprehensive data collection strategy that integrates remote sensing and ground-based observations to enhance the accuracy of hydrological models in alpine regions.
Request/Directive.Answer: A comprehensive data collection strategy in alpine regions could involve integrating remote sensing data with ground-based observations from an observation network of automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) and specialized superstations for snow and frozen ground monitoring. This approach can provide high-resolution soil physics datasets and capture snow accumulation and ablation processes, enhancing the accuracy of hydrological models by providing accurate forcing data and validating remote sensing products.
